title: Functions and Graphs
content:
Module 2, Lesson 5: Functions and Graphs

Introduction

A function f: A → B assigns to each element of the domain A exactly one element of the codomain B. Functions are the central objects of analysis. Their graphs — curves in the xy-plane — visualise relationships between quantities and reveal properties like intercepts, symmetry, maxima, and minima.

Key Concepts

1. Definition of a Function

The vertical line test: a curve represents a function iff every vertical line intersects it at most once. The domain is the set of valid inputs; the range is the set of actual outputs.

2. Types of Functions

Linear (degree 1), quadratic (degree 2), polynomial (degree n), rational (ratio of polynomials), exponential (bˣ), logarithmic (log x), trigonometric (sin, cos), and piecewise functions are the main types.

3. Function Transformations

Starting from y = f(x): vertical shift y = f(x) + c (up c); horizontal shift y = f(x – c) (right c); reflection y = –f(x) (about x-axis); vertical stretch y = cf(x). Combining these transforms any base function.

4. Composition and Inverse

Composition (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)) — apply g first, then f. The inverse function f⁻¹ satisfies f(f⁻¹(x)) = x. Its graph is the reflection of f across y = x. f⁻¹ exists iff f is one-to-one (bijective).

Summary

Functions formalise input-output relationships. You learned the vertical line test, types of functions, transformations, and composition/inverse operations. Functions are the main language of calculus and mathematical analysis.
